# How to deploy a smart contract on an EVM chain’s testnet

I needed to deploy a smart contract for a project I’m working on. Here’s a
rundown of how I did it.

 _> >>_ ** _This guide will NOT explain how to write a smart contract_** _,
only how to deploy one. <<<_

 _For this current stage of my project, I am just testing a sample contract
and I will assume that you already have a contract prepared that you wish to
deploy._

## Introduction

The Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) is built upon the Solidity language. Many
other chains have adopted the same language to create their own ecosystems,
which conveniently allows smart contracts that are coded in Solidity to be
compatible between these chains.

Well-known EVM-based/compatible chains include:

  * Ethereum (obviously)
  * Tron
  * Binance Smart Chain
  * Avalanche

For a more comprehensive list **see here**.

I will be using **Fantom** for my test, but you can use whichever you like.

## 1.

First, you need to have the Metamask wallet installed on your browser (or some
other wallet that allows testnets) and add the testnet and mainnet networks
that you want to use.

Metamask

To add Fantom Testnet:

Network Name: Fantom Testnet  
New RPC URL: https://rpc.testnet.fantom.network/  
Chain ID: 4002  
Currency Symbol: FTM  
Block Explorer URL: https://explorer.testnet.fantom.network/

Go to the faucet of your testnet of choice and request tokens to your wallet’s
address. Fantom faucet.

 _When it comes to deploying on mainnet, you will have to buy real tokens._

## 2.

Go to **Remix** — this site allows you to compile and deploy EVM smart
contracts. Create a new file or load one from elsewhere. To make a new file,
select the button and give it a name, then you can begin editing it.

I loaded mine from Github.

Once the code is in the editor hit CTRL+S or the green arrow at the top to
compile it and you will get a message from the Solidity symbol on the lefthand
pane if the code is approved (note - this does not mean there are no bugs in
it!).

After the smart contract is compiled, you can deploy it.

## 3.

Click on the _Deploy_ button on the lefthand pane (Ethereum symbol) to go to
the _Deploy_ page.

For _Environment_ , select “Injected Provider — Metamask”. This will connect
your Metamask wallet to Remix and assign the network that MM is connected to
(which should be the testnet you’re planning to use) as the network that the
smart contract will deploy to.

You will know if the wallet is correctly connected because “Account” should
show your wallet’s address and the balance of the network you’re connected to.
If the balance isn’t right, try to reconnect your wallet, because you don’t
want to deploy to the wrong network and accidentally pay real funds for gas.

Hit the orange “Deploy” button to initialise the smart contract deployment.
You will be prompted by your wallet to pay the gas fee for deployment. Confirm
it.

## 4.

With the smart contract deployed, you will be able to see the contract’s
address and buttons that will allow you to use its functions. There will also
be a readout in the console in bottom-right.

You can use the contract address to search for the contract in its network’s
explorer. You can also send funds to that address if need be, but make sure
you are willing to lose any funds sent, or have a way to return them before
sending any significant amounts.

 **Fantom Testnet Explorer:**

My test smart contract with funds added

 _At this point, I decided to deploy the smart contract on Polygon’s Mumbai
testnet instead. This showed how compatible the EVM chains are because I
didn’t need to edit any of the contract to deploy it. I just refreshed Remix,
recompiled the contract and changed which network my Metamask wallet was
connected to when I redeployed it. It even had the same contract address._

Redployed on Polygon Mumbai testnet

You can test your contract on the testnet to make sure that all the functions
work as intended by using the buttons on the lefthand side. You will be
prompted to pay the gas fee for each function you interact with.

Testing functions

## Part 1 Conclusion

With my smart contract successfully deployed on Polygon’s testnet, I will end
this part of the guide so I have time to play around with it. I’ll continue
the guide when it becomes time to deploy on mainnet.

Thanks for reading, see you again soon.
